description: Dragon Bridge (Cau Rong) is the world's largest dragon-shaped steel bridge, spanning 666 meters across the Han River in Da Nang, Vietnam. Opened on March 29, 2013, to commemorate the 38th anniversary of Da Nang's liberation, this architectural marvel cost 1.7 trillion Vietnamese dong (US$88 million) and took four years to complete. Designed by American engineering firms Ammann & Whitney Consulting Engineers and Louis Berger Group, the bridge won a global design competition against 18 entries from Vietnam, Japan, and Germany. The steel dragon measures 568 meters in length and weighs a staggering 9,000 tons, with its head alone weighing 194 tons. The dragon's style follows the Ly Dynasty (1009-1225) aesthetic, a symbol of Vietnamese royal power, and faces the ocean rather than the mainland. The bridge's tail is artistically styled to resemble a blooming lotus flower, Vietnam's national symbol representing peaceful rural life. Coated with five layers of anti-corrosion paint that give it a stunning golden hue, the bridge serves as both a vital transportation link connecting Da Nang International Airport to the city's main roads and My Khe Beach, and as the city's most iconic modern landmark.
highlights: The dragon breathes real fire and sprays water every Friday, Saturday, and Sunday at 9:00 PM in a spectacular 15-minute show featuring nine bursts of fire followed by three rounds of water spray, all controlled by a dedicated team of "dragon workers" operating from inside the structure.

The bridge features 15,000 LED lights that transform it into a dazzling rainbow display at night, with colors changing every few minutes to create an ever-shifting kaleidoscope effect visible from across the city.

At 666 meters long and 37.5 meters wide, the bridge carries six lanes of traffic and weighs 9,000 tons total, with the dragon's body alone consisting of 8,400 tons of steel held in place by cables designed to withstand typhoons and earthquakes.
The dragon features 39 meticulously crafted scales weighing 118 tons total, remarkably completed in just one week during construction, each contributing to the creature's realistic appearance.

The dragon's head weighs 194 tons and houses the fire-breathing mechanism, while the tail weighs 19.37 tons and is artistically designed to resemble a blooming lotus flower, creating a powerful symbol that combines Vietnamese strength and peace.

The bridge was designed by American firms after winning an international competition in 2007, with construction beginning on July 19, 2009, when former Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung attended the groundbreaking ceremony.

The bridge's unique arch-beam-wire combination steel structure makes it the world's most innovative dragon-shaped bridge, combining steel beams, steel arches, and concrete beams in a way never before attempted.

During the fire and water show, thousands of locals and tourists gather on the bridge and surrounding streets, creating a festive carnival-like atmosphere every weekend that transforms the riverside into Da Nang's premier social gathering spot.
tips: Arrive by 8:15-8:30 PM on Friday, Saturday, or Sunday for the fire show, as the bridge closes to traffic before 9:00 PM and the best viewing spots fill up quickly with both locals and tourists.

Position yourself 100 meters from the dragon's head on either the left or right side for the best views of the fire show without getting soaked during the water spray phase, which can thoroughly drench anyone standing too close.

Bring a tripod for night photography and use manual camera settings with long exposure to capture the LED light displays and fire show, as the lighting requires longer exposure times for sharp images.

Visit riverside cafes along Bach Dang Street or Tran Hung Dao Street an hour before the show to secure a comfortable seat with drinks at local prices, avoiding the crowded standing areas on the bridge itself.
View the bridge from Tran Thi Ly Bridge downstream to capture both bridges in one shot with the glowing city skyline as a backdrop, offering a unique perspective unavailable from ground level.
Visit on weekday evenings to enjoy the colorful LED light show without the massive weekend crowds, experiencing the bridge's beauty in a more relaxed atmosphere while still getting impressive photos.
Consider taking a Han River cruise that times its route to position you perfectly for the fire show, offering comfortable seating and avoiding the chaos of standing in packed crowds on the streets.
Explore Son Tra Night Market (Cho Dem Son Tra) within a few minutes' walk of the bridge before or after the show, combining the experience with authentic local street food and shopping.
If photographing from the bridge during the show, be prepared for dense crowds and limited space, and protect your camera equipment from water spray and jostling spectators.
Visit at sunset for the best natural lighting transition, watching as the golden paint reflects the setting sun before the LED lights take over after dark.

Skip the fire show entirely if you have limited time in Da Nang, as the bridge is equally impressive lit up on any evening, and many travelers find the brief 15-minute show overhyped compared to simply admiring the architecture.
Download the specific schedule before visiting, as show times occasionally change during major Vietnamese holidays like Tet, when additional performances may be added.
vibe: Dragon Bridge pulses with two distinct personalities depending on when you visit. On weekday evenings, it offers a serene urban spectacle, its golden scales glowing softly against the night sky as traffic flows steadily beneath the LED rainbow that shifts through colors every few minutes. The riverside walkways attract couples and families strolling peacefully, with the Han River's gentle flow reflecting the bridge's kaleidoscopic light show. But on weekend nights, especially approaching 9:00 PM, the atmosphere transforms into something closer to a street carnival. Thousands of people flood the bridge and surrounding streets, vendors set up impromptu drink stalls on sidewalks, and the energy builds to a fever pitch as traffic stops and spectators claim their spots. The moment the dragon breathes fire, accompanied by gasps and cheers from the crowd, feels both theatrical and communal, with locals treating it as much a social gathering as a tourist attraction. The bridge successfully straddles the line between functional infrastructure and entertainment venue, remaining fundamentally a working bridge that just happens to put on a show. It embodies Da Nang's modern ambitions while honoring traditional Vietnamese symbolism, creating a uniquely contemporary Vietnamese experience that feels neither too commercial nor too reverential.
expectations: The fire-breathing show will be a dramatic, extended spectacle lasting 20-30 minutes with multiple different effects and choreographed lighting sequences.
The bridge is primarily a tourist attraction designed for visitors, similar to other famous bridges that serve mainly as landmarks rather than functional infrastructure.
The best viewing experience requires purchasing tickets for rooftop restaurants, boat tours, or special viewing platforms to get worthwhile photos and views.
The dragon looks massive and realistic from all angles, with intricate details visible throughout the entire structure that make it appear like a real creature.
The area around the bridge is quiet and dedicated to tourists, with organized viewing areas and limited local presence during shows.
reality: The fire and water show lasts only 15 minutes and repeats the same action throughout—nine fire bursts followed by three water sprays—which many visitors find repetitive and "boring" after the initial excitement, with some calling it "one of the most overrated tourist attractions in the world."

The bridge is a fully functioning six-lane traffic bridge used by locals daily for commuting between the airport and city beaches, only closing to vehicles during the weekend shows, making it more utilitarian than many expect.

The best viewing spots are completely free along the riverside walkways and streets, with cheap local cafes offering seats for the price of a drink (often just a few dollars), while boat tours and rooftop bars are optional upgrades rather than necessities.

From ground level and most viewing angles, the dragon appears as an abstract golden steel structure rather than a realistic creature, with the full dragon shape only truly apparent from aerial views or distant vantage points like Tran Thi Ly Bridge downstream.

Thousands of locals attend every weekend show, often outnumbering tourists, treating it as a beloved community gathering spot where families bring children and friends meet for drinks at sidewalk stalls, creating an authentic local carnival atmosphere rather than a sanitized tourist experience.
unique_facts: An entire team of "dragon caretakers" from Da Nang Bridge and Road Joint Stock Company works inside the dragon's steel body, accessing a hidden interior system to maintain and control the fire and water shows from within the structure.
The bridge's length of 666 meters was an intentional design choice, and the dragon features exactly 39 scales that were fabricated and installed in just one week during the construction phase.
The dragon's head alone weighs 194 tons—equivalent to about 130 cars—and contains the sophisticated fire-breathing mechanism that safely shoots flames while positioned above six lanes of traffic.

The bridge is held together by a complex cable system specifically engineered to keep the 9,000-ton dragon stable during Vietnam's powerful typhoons and potential earthquakes, with five layers of specialized anti-corrosion paint protecting it from the tropical coastal climate.
The dragon faces toward the ocean rather than inland, a deliberate decision made by Da Nang officials to symbolize the city's outward-looking ambitions and future-focused development.

The bridge was inaugurated exactly 38 years after Da Nang's liberation (March 29, 1975), making the opening date a deliberate commemoration of the city's historical turning point during the Vietnam War.

The winning design came from American engineering firms despite strong local entries, triumphing over 18 finalists from Vietnam, Japan, and Germany in a 2007 international competition that specifically sought a design representing Vietnamese culture.

The dragon's tail transforms into a lotus flower design, combining two of Vietnam's most powerful symbols—the dragon representing royal power and the lotus representing the peaceful countryside—into one continuous sculptural element.

The LED lighting system contains exactly 15,000 individual lights that can be programmed in endless combinations, creating the constantly changing color displays that make every evening viewing experience slightly different.

Each weekend fire show includes precisely nine fire bursts per round across two rounds—18 total bursts—followed by exactly three water spray rounds with one spray each, a sequence that never varies and is programmed to mathematical precision.

The bridge's official opening in 2013 made it the newest of Da Nang's iconic Han River crossings, yet it instantly became the most photographed, overshadowing the older Love Bridge, Han River Bridge, and even the sail-shaped Tran Thi Ly Bridge in tourist popularity.

If you ask any Da Nang local what makes their city unique, they overwhelmingly mention Dragon Bridge first, demonstrating how quickly a 12-year-old structure became the city's primary cultural identifier.
surprises: Standing near the dragon's head during the water spray phase will leave you absolutely soaking wet—not just damp but thoroughly drenched—as the spray is far more powerful than promotional materials suggest, catching unprepared tourists off guard every weekend.

The bridge looks significantly different from ground level compared to promotional photos, appearing more as an abstract golden steel arch than a recognizable dragon, with many visitors initially struggling to identify the creature's features from street viewpoints.

Locals attend the fire show in huge numbers every single weekend despite having seen it hundreds of times, treating it as a social ritual and community gathering rather than a one-time spectacle, with entire families making it part of their weekly routine.

The bridge remains open for pedestrian traffic during most evenings, allowing you to walk directly underneath and even inside the dragon's body structure, providing an industrial perspective that contrasts sharply with the elegant exterior appearance.

Cheap sidewalk drink stalls with plastic stools offer some of the best viewing experiences for just a few dollars, creating a more authentic and comfortable atmosphere than expensive rooftop venues while providing nearly identical views.

The fire show involves actual smoke and strong fire-smell that lingers in the air after each burst, giving the experience a surprisingly visceral quality beyond just visual spectacle, with some visitors finding the smell overwhelming.

The LED color changes are constant and automatic, not choreographed to music or timed to specific moments, resulting in a randomized rainbow effect that can clash with photos rather than enhancing them, especially during the fire show when colors shift mid-performance.

Many travelers who visit specifically for the fire show later admit they found it anticlimactic and overhyped, with the general consensus being that the bridge is more impressive as a permanently illuminated architectural feature than as a weekend show venue.

Son Tra Night Market sits just minutes away but remains largely unknown to tourists who focus solely on the bridge, meaning most visitors miss the nearby authentic local street food and shopping scene that locals consider equally essential to the area's appeal.

The bridge serves as the main route to My Khe Beach and Non Nuoc Beach, meaning thousands of tourists drive across it during daylight without realizing they've crossed the famous Dragon Bridge, as it appears completely ordinary in natural light without the golden glow.

Traffic is completely stopped about 15 minutes before the 9:00 PM show, with the six-lane bridge rapidly filling with viewers on foot, creating a surreal scene of pedestrians suddenly flooding a major highway that was busy with cars just moments before.

The bridge's five layers of anti-corrosion paint are responsible for its golden color rather than gold-toned metal or special lighting, meaning the "golden dragon" effect exists 24/7 but only becomes dramatic after dark when artificial lighting reveals the color's true intensity.
